ygData.subject: Walking in Zero-G Novelty Search
ygData.msgSnippet: Peter, That is a fascinating experiment with the zero-gravity novelty search. Would you consider uploading it so we can see the walkers and swimmers evolve?

Peter,

That is a fascinating experiment with the zero-gravity novelty sear=
ch.
 Would you consider uploading it so we can see the walkers and
swimmers=
 evolve?

One question I have is when you say you get walkers "100% of the
=
time," you mean they look like that are walking, but they are not
actually =
walking right?  That is, these "walkers" are really just
floating in mid-ai=
r, and if you actually placed them on the ground
with gravity, they would p=
robably not balance?  Similarly, the
swimmers may or may not swim in the fr=
iction of water?  In other words
you are discovering the aesthetic look of =
various activities but not
necessarily the mechanical nuances?

Assuming I =
am understanding that correctly, there is still a puzzle to
get them to go =
straight to walking on hard ground through novelty
search.   But I think yo=
u're oscillation-detection novelty
characterization is quite clever and is =
progress in that direction.
Very interesting work overall! 

ken

--- In ne=
at@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi=
 Jeff, 
> 
> I am glad that you like my program and enjoy it! :) 
> 
> I kn=
ow it would be cool to browse the archive, or have an external 
> routine t=
hat queries the archive by different criteria to show me 
> what was achiev=
ed during the run, but this program now is actually a 
> stepping stone for=
 another research project I have, evolving leaky-
> integrator substrates b=
y HyperNEAT combined with evolving the 
> substrate itself, all used in one=
 Alife simulation of mass-spring 
> creatures, sensing collision and reacti=
ng by contracting the springs. 
> And all this with Novelty Search searchin=
g for new and new behaviors. 
> I believe that this is a pretty serious tes=
t of how far complexity 
> can go in such open-ended domain. I can later mi=
x it with fitness 
> search once a good population has evolved, on objectiv=
es 
> like "swimming". 
> 
> Let me mention about one interesting experimen=
t I made with the NS 
> NEVH. I restricted the substrate connectivity so th=
at output->output 
> connections are not queried. Then I made the environme=
nt to 0 gravity 
> and removed the ground plane. The behavior characterizat=
ion was 
> changed like this. The behavior data is a vector of 15 doubles 
=
> representing the outputs. Each time an output oscillates (going to 
> +tr=
eshold and then -treshold, or vice versa), its corresponding place 
> in th=
e vector is incremented. 
> So the vector is actually counting how many osc=
illations the outputs 
> did during the lifetime. A substrate oscillating w=
ith high frequency 
> is very far in the behavior space. Different outputs =
oscillating are 
> counted too. The behavior distance metric is the eucledi=
an distance 
> between these 15-D vectors. 
> 
> So novelty search now has =
to find new ways to oscillate the entire 
> body, to do repeating movements=
. In all the runs, Novelty Search with 
> HyperNEAT finds walking gaits 100=
% of the time, in the first 1000 
> evaluations. There are also swimming ga=
its and all kind of stuff (I 
> saw one individual actually dancing :)) 
> =

> So what was stopping it from walking before, is the gravity. Keeping 
> =
balance on one leg and trying to walk at the same time turns out to 
> be v=
ery hard task. One environmental constraint that would be useful 
> to make=
 it walk is, when only one foot has stepped on the ground, 
> stick that fo=
ot to the ground. So the chance the humanoid to fall is 
> minimized. 
> 
>=
 As for the novelty search stagnation, where getting new behaviors 
> becom=
es hard, the population begins to do something like a random 
> probing any=
thing that is not the same stuff. Then it begins to rely 
> entirely on mut=
ation to get out somehow. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jef=
f Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >
> > I finally borrowed a windows machine from =
someone and looked at 
> this. It's
> > really fun to watch! I am leaving i=
t running overnight to see what 
> happens.
> > So far the best I have seen=
 has been about a five mini-step shuffle
> > backwards...although I have se=
en a few three mini-step forward 
> shuffles.
> > 
> > Can you post either =
the genome and or a movie of the best org 
> you've seen so
> > far? 
> > 
=
> > I second the notion that it would be cool to browse the archive, 
> esp=
ecially
> > if you could choose archive members to view based on max distan=
ce 
> from 0,0
> > or something like that.
> > 
> > It might help you to vi=
sualize things if you added another viewing 
> mode that
> > put a dot in t=
he 3D viewer for every x,y,z coordinate in the 
> archive (one
> > color) a=
nd in the current population (another color).
> > 
> > Watching this also m=
akes me wonder about the population losing its 
> gradient
> > and disengag=
ing. Here is the potential concern (and I think mattias 
> and ken
> > disc=
ussed this already): Once all the easy to access points are 
> found, if
> =
> most of the orgs are not getting somewhere new, they will all have 
> equ=
al
> > fitnesses and the search will not be focused on the outside edge. 
>=
 Do you
> > think this is happening (and might this be why David mentioned =
that 
> he saw a
> > lot of repeats toward the end)? The visualization I ju=
st proposed 
> might help
> > on this front. Do the points added in the arc=
hive tend to be 
> further and
> > further away from 0,0....or is it just f=
illing in the spaces in the 
> nearby
> > vicinity? 
> > 
> > Despite these=
 concerns/suggestions, it is very fun stuff to look 
> at...and
> > its exc=
iting that you are hybridizing these ideas so quickly and 
> testing
> > th=
em. 
> > 
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > Jeff Clune
> > 
> > Digital Evolution Lab, M=
ichigan State University
